results.title: They found a cave; Waxworks (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Andrew Steane, Charles E. Wolnizer and Australian Council for Children's Film and Television
results.brief_description: They found a cave: Four English orphans migrate to Tasmania under the care of their Aunt. Their Aunt becomes sick and is hospitalised, leaving the children to seek refuge in a secret cave. Excitement follows the children as they face danger and adventure in the rugged terrain before they are finally reunited with their Aunt. Based on the novel by Nan Chauncy. “Waxworks”: A short tale about children lost in a waxworks museum “House of Horrors”.

results.title: They don't teach them like they used to (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: John Honey and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Focuses on the discussion between parents and teachers concerning the contrast between current teaching methods and those used a generation ago in the schools of Australia.

results.title: They do come back
results.brief_description: Roy and Julie, two young working people, plan to marry, but TB interrupts their plans. Roy has advanced tuberculosis, and Julie is an early case. The film shows their town’s health facilities going into action to help these two young people; case-finding, diagnosis, and hospitalisation are demonstrated. Both Roy and Julie are admitted to a sanatorium, and after treatment, both are able to return to work, and to complete their plans for a home of their own.

results.title: They chose peace
results.brief_description: Documentary account of the International Carnival of Youth for Peace and Friendship held in Sydney in March 1952. The film includes a summary of their support to the carnival and its principles, but it also shows the direct interference from the Menzies Government that attempted to stir popular antipathy and slander.

results.title: They can do it
results.creator_credit: Lore Rasmussen, Allan Leitman and Education Development Centre
results.brief_description: Traces the development of an infant teacher’s approach to a class over a period of eight months at Pastorious Public School, Philadelphia. Initial traditional methods gain little response from her negro and underprivileged students. On introduction of a more relaxed and individual teaching program, the children become more involved with their surroundings and teacher.

results.title: They can be saved
results.creator_credit: Greg Parry and Queensland. Dept. of Education
results.brief_description: An interview on location which looks at the work of the Queensland Beach Protection Authority. Discusses the causes of beach erosion and the ways of preventing future destruction.

results.title: They came to Wales
results.creator_credit: Barry Clayton, James Ritchie, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: This kaleidoscopic film shows the new industrial Wales of nuclear power and electronics, of jet aircraft and optical glass developing in the older Wales of mountain, seascape and good company. We meet people who came to Wales from abroad and have found a new industrial and social life there.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Clayton, James Ritchie, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films

results.title: They came to Cordura
results.creator_credit: Robert Rossen, William Goetz and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Set during a Mexican expedition in 1916, Gary Cooper is cast as a self doubting Army Major, who believing himself to be a coward, relieves himself of his combat duties and is assigned the inglorious task of locating five battle heroes and ensuring their safe passage to the Cordura military base. The five heroes are worthy of a medal of honour, something that appeals to the “cowardly” Army Major. The mission is going along smoothly until the arrival of an American woman accused of treason (Rita Hayworth), as the film evolves into an intense study of character and endurance. Cast also includes Van Heflin and Tab Hunter.
